[LIST_ITEM] Arachidonic Acid can be produced two ways
[LIST_ITEM] Via PLA to make lysophospholipid and arachidonic acid
[LIST_ITEM] Via PLC to make DAG and phosphoryl-R then DAG lipase to make arachidonic acid and monacylglycerol
[LIST_ITEM] Cell Specificity of Arachidonic Acid Derivatives
[LIST_ITEM] Biological Functions of Arachidonic Acid Products
[LIST_ITEM] Arachidonic acid in hypothalamus converted to PGE2 (NSAIDs inhibit)
○ Regulates pain (PGE2 interacts w/ pain receptors) ○ Regulates blood flow ○ Regulates leukocyte activity ○ Rheumatoid arthritis
[LIST_ITEM] Altered IgG leads to fixation/activation of complements
[LIST_ITEM] Lysosomal enzymes and activated oxygen released
[LIST_ITEM] Phospholipases releases arachidonic acid from membranes --> PG --> nerve sensitization and vasodilation
[LIST_ITEM] Suppress the release of arachidonic acid (no substrate available)
[LIST_ITEM] Blocks both COX and LO-derived products ○ Modulate COX activity
[LIST_ITEM] PGI2 in gastric cells for protection
[LIST_ITEM] Pro-inflammatory PGs and other mediators lead to
[LIST_ITEM] Inflammation ○ Modulate specific enzymes down-stream from COX
[LIST_ITEM] Thromboxane synthetase inhibitors ○ Modulate LO activity
[LIST_ITEM] Small molecule receptor antagonists for cysteinyl leukotrienes
[LIST_ITEM] NSAIDs ○ Aspirin, IB, indomethacin, acetaminophen ○ COX-2 Inhibitors
[LIST_ITEM] Osteoarthritis, rheumatoid, primary dysmenorrhea, pain mgmt ○ Aspirin
[LIST_ITEM] Irreversible inhibition of COX by acetylation at active site
[LIST_ITEM] But b/c platelets don't reproduce and endothelial cells can make more COX, aspirin has an anti-thrombotic month --> reduced risk of heart attack/stroke
[LIST_ITEM] Aspiring inhibits platelet aggregation by blocking platelet thromboxane production
[LIST_ITEM] Blocks platelet COX for life of platelet b/c no new protein synthesis occurs
[LIST_ITEM] Can block endothelial cell-derived prostacyclin, but short-lived by cell produces new COX
[LIST_ITEM] Platelet activity blocked more than endothelial cell activity ○ Indomethacin, ibuprofen reversibly inhibit COX

[LIST_ITEM] Lipid mediators of inflammation ○ COX1+2 --> prostaglandins (PGE2, PGI2) ○ COX-1: thromboxanes ○ 5-LO: LTB4, C4, D4 ○ Vasodilation, increased vascular permeability, control of platelet aggregation, chemotaxis, pain, fever ○ Balance between
[LIST_ITEM] NSAIDs inhibits both, COXIBs inhibit COX-2
[LIST_ITEM] Ibuprofen reversibly inhibits both leading to a balance, maybe a little anti-thrombotic
[LIST_ITEM] COX-2 (vioxx) inhibits COX-2 favoring thrombosis --> cardiogenic effects and why vioxx was pulled
[LIST_ITEM] Aspirin irreversibly inhibits both, but as discussed before, COX-2 is truly irreversible vs. COX-1 being produced by endothelial cells --> anti-thrombotic effects of aspirin
